Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Three-oscillator subtractive synthesizer feeding the FL Studio Sampler engine for basic synthesis tasks
Best Used For: Super saw leads and detuned plucks
What It Excels At: Trance super saws and Dutch leads

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Clean, digital, slightly aliased during playback (anti-aliased on render). Classic subtractive character with simple waveforms.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Linear velocity response through FL Sampler. No built-in dynamics beyond envelope control.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Pure mathematical waveforms (sine, triangle, square, saw, smooth saw). Harmonic content depends on waveform selection. Supports custom waveforms.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Three oscillators mix together -> FL Sampler engine (filter, envelope, LFO) -> output. OSC 3 can function as AM modulator for OSC 1 & 2.
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Subtractive synthesis with three independent oscillators, each with waveform selection, pitch, phase, and detune controls
Key Modules / Sections: Oscillator 3 (with level control and AM mode toggle)
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Stereo created via phase offset and detune parameters. Each oscillator has separate L/R phase and detune settings.

Primary Controls: Waveform selectors (sine, triangle, square, saw, smooth saw, custom)
Modulation Capabilities: Inherits FL Sampler modulation (2 LFOs, 2 envelopes)
Macro-Style Controls: Phase Randomness acts as macro stereo width
AM mode provides quick modulation routing

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Good starter presets covering common use cases. Thousands of community presets available.
Preset Categories: Leads (super saw, hot leads, Dutch leads, pop leads)
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Presets found in Browser under /Channel Presets/3x Oscillator. Compatible with FL Studio Mobile.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.CPU Usage: Extremely low (~0.2% per instance). Anti-aliasing disabled during playback, enabled during render for CPU efficiency.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Latency: Negligible. Inherits FL Sampler latency characteristics.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Real-Time Suitability: Excellent. One of the most CPU-efficient synths in FL Studio.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Scaling with Polyphony: Scales linearly but remains very efficient. Can run dozens of instances without issue.

Automation & Integration.Automation Friendliness: Excellent. All parameters automatable via FL's standard automation system.
Automation & Integration.Link to Controller: Full MIDI learn support. Can link any parameter to hardware controllers.
Automation & Integration.Patcher Compatibility: Fully compatible. Works seamlessly in Patcher for complex routing.
FL-Specific Features: Envelope and LFO from Sampler engine

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Direct to mixer channel. Often layered with other synths for texture. Commonly routed through Fruity Fast Dist or Soundgoodizer.
Beginner Mistakes: Forgetting OSC 1 has no level control (always at 100%)
Over-detuning causing phase cancellation
Not using phase offset for width
Ignoring the AM mode on OSC 3
Expecting complex modulation without understanding Sampler engine
Pro Tips: Layer multiple 3x Osc instances with slight detune for super saws
Use phase offset instead of detune for cleaner stereo
OSC 3 AM mode creates instant timbral complexity
Render with anti-aliasing for cleaner high frequencies
Combine with Sytrus for hybrid tones
Use as CPU-efficient layer beneath heavy synths

Known Limitations: No built-in effects or complex modulation
Relies on FL Sampler for filtering/envelopes
Cannot compete with modern advanced synths
When NOT to Use It: When workflow speed isn't priority over sound design depth

Learning Curve & Skill Level.Ease of Use: Very easy. Beginner-friendly interface with minimal parameters.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Time to Productivity: Immediate. Can create usable sounds within minutes.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Visual Feedback Quality: Minimal. Waveform selection is visual but no oscilloscope or spectrum display.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Documentation Quality: Excellent. Well-documented in FL Studio manual with community tutorials abundant.

Major Changes Over Time: Integration improvements with Sampler engine updates
Version Notes & Evolution (Optional).Backward Compatibility Notes: Fully backward compatible. Projects from FL Studio 1 work in current versions.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Additive synthesis-based preset generator with 4,294,967,296 algorithmically-generated presets based on Ogun engine
Best Used For: Sound design inspiration and happy accidents
Discovering sounds to recreate in Ogun
What It Excels At: Fast workflow for producers who prefer browsing to designing
Integration with Ogun for deeper editing

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Highly variable. Ranges from classic analog tones to modern digital textures. Includes Soundgoodizer processing via Magic Dust control.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Depends on preset. Generally linear response with Soundgoodizer compression when Magic Dust is active.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Additive synthesis engine creates sounds by layering sine waves. Harmonic content varies wildly by preset number.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Ogun additive synthesis engine -> Soundgoodizer (Magic Dust) -> output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Additive synthesis (layering individual sine waves). Preset number determines oscillator configuration and harmonic content.
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Inherent stereo field based on preset algorithm. Soundgoodizer can affect stereo width.

Modulation Capabilities: Limited. Magic Dust and Volume are automatable.
Full modulation available when transferring to Ogun

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Highly variable. Some presets are musical, many are experimental or unusable. Quality depends on random generation.
Best Starting Presets: Transfer promising presets to Ogun for refinement
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Non-traditional browser. Enter number or randomize. Hover over info button to see current preset number. Write down favorites.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.CPU Usage: Moderate. Lower quality settings reduce CPU. Additive synthesis is more CPU-intensive than subtractive.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Latency: Minimal. Standard FL Studio plugin latency.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Real-Time Suitability: Good with quality settings adjusted. Use lower quality for live performance.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Scaling with Polyphony: CPU scales with voice count. Multiple instances can become demanding.

Automation & Integration.Automation Friendliness: Limited. Only Volume and Magic Dust automatable. Preset changes not automatable.
Automation & Integration.Link to Controller: Basic MIDI learn for Volume and Magic Dust. Preset number not MIDI-controllable in practical way.
Automation & Integration.Patcher Compatibility: Fully compatible but limited routing options compared to Ogun.
FL-Specific Features: Direct integration with Ogun (transfer presets by number)

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Direct to mixer. Often used for sound discovery then transferred to Ogun for processing.
Beginner Mistakes: Not writing down preset numbers of favorites
Expecting consistent quality across all presets
Using high quality setting unnecessarily (CPU waste)
Not understanding Magic Dust affects final sound
Forgetting to transfer good presets to Ogun for customization
Pro Tips: Always note preset numbers (hover over info button)
Use Ogun to edit and save favorite Autogun presets
Set Magic Dust to zero when transferring to Ogun for accurate sound
Use quality selector to optimize CPU during production
Create a text file of favorite preset numbers
Most presets have never been heard - explore freely

Known Limitations: No sound design parameters (preset browsing only)
Cannot save custom presets within Autogun
Magic Dust baked into sound (not in Ogun transfer)
When NOT to Use It: When needing precise sound design control

Learning Curve & Skill Level.Ease of Use: Very easy. Click random or enter number. Minimal learning required.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Time to Productivity: Immediate. Finding usable sounds may take time due to randomness.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Visual Feedback Quality: Minimal. No waveform or spectrum display. Just preset number info.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Documentation Quality: Good. Manual explains functionality. Community shares favorite preset numbers.

Version Notes & Evolution (Optional).Backward Compatibility Notes: Fully compatible. Preset numbers work across all versions.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Flexible kick drum synthesizer with dual oscillators and sample layering for creating custom bass drum sounds
Best Used For: Custom kick design with click control

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Modern, punchy, synthesized kick character with warm saturation options. Clean to aggressive depending on settings.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Responsive to velocity. Attack, sustain, and decay envelope controls shape dynamics.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Dual oscillator design allows tonal shaping. Saturation adds harmonic richness. Sub-bass control provides fundamental reinforcement.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Main Oscillator + Slave Oscillator -> Sample Layer -> Click Section -> Sub-Bass Enhancement -> Saturation/Drive -> Output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Dual oscillator synthesis with sample layering, pitch envelope shaping, and saturation processing
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Mono-focused (kick drums). Stereo width from sample layer possible.

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Excellent. Covers wide range from clean 808s to aggressive EDM kicks.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Presets accessible via plugin menu. Quick access to common kick types. Drag samples directly onto interface.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.CPU Usage: Low to Moderate. More efficient than complex synthesizers, heavier than simple sample playback.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Real-Time Suitability: Excellent. Designed for live triggering and performance.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Scaling with Polyphony: Minimal impact. Kick drums typically monophonic. CPU usage scales linearly with instances.

Automation & Integration.Automation Friendliness: Excellent. All parameters automatable. Great for kick variations across arrangement.
Automation & Integration.Link to Controller: Full MIDI learn support. Common to map pitch, drive, and sub-bass to controllers.
Automation & Integration.Patcher Compatibility: Fully compatible. Can be integrated into complex drum chains in Patcher.
FL-Specific Features: Drag & drop sample loading from browser

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Direct to mixer kick channel. Often routed through sidechain compression bus. EQ and compression in mixing stage.
Beginner Mistakes: Over-driving saturation causing distortion
Too much sub-bass (muddy mix)
Ignoring click section for attack
Not using pitch envelope for punch
Forgetting to sidechain bass elements
Sample layer volume too high/low
Pro Tips: Layer with samples for unique character
Automate pitch slightly for groove
Use click section sparingly for clarity
Sub-bass control replaces separate 808 layer
Duplicate with variations for fills
Use Fruity Fast Dist before BassDrum for analog warmth
Reference kick with spectrum analyzer
Sidechain compress bass/pads to kick channel

When NOT to Use It: For snare, clap, or hi-hat synthesis
In acoustic or live drum contexts

Learning Curve & Skill Level.Ease of Use: Easy to Moderate. Interface is clear but understanding synthesis helps.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Time to Productivity: Fast. Good starting presets. 5-10 minutes to understand controls.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Visual Feedback Quality: Good. Clear parameter labels. No waveform display but intuitive layout.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Documentation Quality: Good. FL manual covers all functions. Community tutorials available.

Version Notes & Evolution (Optional).Backward Compatibility Notes: Fully backward compatible since FL 11. Projects using BassDrum work in all subsequent versions.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Spectral synthesizer that converts bitmap images into sound by scanning left to right and translating colors/brightness to frequencies and amplitude

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Highly variable, often metallic, bell-like, or formant-rich. Character depends entirely on source image. Can range from pure tones to complex noise.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Static unless image changes or parameters automated. Responds to MIDI velocity through FL Sampler integration.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Spectral content mirrors image vertical position (frequency) and color/brightness (amplitude). Red=left channel, green=right channel, yellow=both. Complex harmonic relationships.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Image loaded -> Vertical line scans left to right -> RGB values translated to stereo sine waves -> Frequency position determines pitch -> Loop/grain processing -> Output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Spectral synthesis via bitmap scanning. Additive synthesis of sine waves determined by image pixel data.
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Red pixels = left channel amplitude, Green pixels = right channel amplitude, Yellow = centered. Widen mode enhances stereo separation.

Primary Controls: Frequency knob (sets frequency range for entire bitmap)
Voice count box (sine waves per note, affects density)

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Limited traditional presets. Comes with example images. Sound quality depends on image selection and parameter tweaking.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: No traditional preset system. Workflow centers on importing/creating images. Save channel states for recall.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.CPU Usage: Low to Moderate. Depends on voice count setting. Higher voice counts increase CPU usage.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Real-Time Suitability: Good for pads and sustained sounds. Less suitable for percussive real-time playing.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Scaling with Polyphony: CPU scales with voice count and polyphony. Multiple notes with high voice count can be demanding.

Automation & Integration.Automation Friendliness: Good. Frequency, Length, and mode toggles automatable. Great for evolving textures.
Automation & Integration.Link to Controller: Standard MIDI learn. Frequency and Length commonly mapped. Voice count typically static.
Automation & Integration.Patcher Compatibility: Fully compatible. Works well in Patcher for complex routing and image-switching setups.
FL-Specific Features: Drag & drop image loading from browser/Windows

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Direct to mixer with heavy effects (reverb, delay, ping-pong delay). Often routed through filters and modulation.
Beginner Mistakes: Using overly complex images (too noisy)
Not understanding color-to-channel mapping
Ignoring voice count impact on CPU and timbre
Forgetting to loop for sustained sounds
Not applying effects (sounds dry/harsh alone)
Expecting predictable musical results
Pro Tips: Use simple, high-contrast images for clearer tones
Automate Frequency and Length for evolving sounds
Apply heavy reverb and delay for ambient textures
Grainy mode adds interesting texture variations
Create custom images in paint software for specific spectra
Layer with traditional synths for hybrid sounds
Use spectrograms of vocals for unique formants
Widen mode before stereo effects for spatial depth

Known Limitations: Difficult to create traditional musical sounds
Not suitable for most conventional music production
When NOT to Use It: For traditional bass, leads, or pads
In conventional pop, rock, or hip-hop

Learning Curve & Skill Level.Ease of Use: Moderate. Simple interface but understanding image-to-sound translation takes experimentation.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Time to Productivity: Slow for musical sounds. Fast for experimental textures. Requires trial-and-error.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Visual Feedback Quality: Minimal. Image is visible but no audio waveform or spectrum display. Visual-to-audio mapping is conceptual.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Documentation Quality: Good. FL manual explains functionality. Community tutorials provide creative examples.

Version Notes & Evolution (Optional).Backward Compatibility Notes: Fully backward compatible. Projects using BeepMap work across versions.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Monophonic bass generator with three-band EQ and portamento slide capability for realistic bass guitar-style performances

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Clean, synthetic bass tone with adjustable frequency response. Simple, focused character without complex harmonics.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Monophonic (one note at a time). Portamento slides when notes overlap. Linear velocity response.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Simple harmonic structure shaped by three-band EQ. Not particularly rich in overtones. Clean fundamental focus.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Bass oscillator -> Three-band EQ (Bass, Mid, Treble) -> Portamento processing -> Output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Simple oscillator-based bass generation with integrated EQ. Monophonic with portamento slide capability.
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Mono output (appropriate for bass). Stereo processing applied via mixer/effects.

Secondary / Advanced Controls: Portamento via piano roll (mono mode + note overlap)
Modulation Capabilities: Portamento via piano roll note arrangement
Standard FL automation for all parameters
Macro-Style Controls: Three-band EQ functions as macro tone control

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Minimal presets. Plugin designed for quick EQ adjustment rather than preset browsing.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: No internal preset system. Save channel states for recall. Focus on EQ adjustment workflow.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.CPU Usage: Very Low. One of the lightest bass synths in FL Studio.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Real-Time Suitability: Excellent. Minimal CPU and latency. Great for live performance.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Scaling with Polyphony: Monophonic only (one voice). No polyphony scaling issues.

Automation & Integration.Automation Friendliness: Excellent. Three EQ knobs easily automated for tonal movement.
Automation & Integration.Link to Controller: Full MIDI learn. Common to map EQ knobs to hardware.
Automation & Integration.Patcher Compatibility: Fully compatible. Often used in bass layering setups in Patcher.
FL-Specific Features: Channel rack and piano roll integration

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Direct to mixer bass channel. Often layered with other bass synths (Sytrus, FLEX) for texture. Processed with distortion and compression.
Beginner Mistakes: Expecting complex timbres (it's simple by design)
Not using portamento for slides
Forgetting to enable mono mode for slides
Over-EQing (subtle adjustments work best)
Using alone without layering or effects
Not leveraging simplicity for quick sketches
Pro Tips: Layer with Flex or Sytrus for complex tones
Use Fruity Fast Dist for analog warmth
Automate EQ for filter-like movement
Enable mono mode in piano roll for slides
Notes must overlap for portamento to trigger
Great as foundation layer in bass stack
Combine with distortion for DnB grit
Use as reference for more complex bass design

Known Limitations: Not suitable as standalone bass in modern productions
When NOT to Use It: For modern high-fidelity bass sounds alone

Learning Curve & Skill Level.Ease of Use: Very Easy. Three knobs, minimal complexity. Beginner-friendly.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Visual Feedback Quality: Minimal. Three knobs only. No waveform display.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Documentation Quality: Good. FL manual covers functionality. Simple enough to explore without manual.

Version Notes & Evolution (Optional).Backward Compatibility Notes: Fully backward compatible across all FL Studio versions.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Integrated single-sample sampler instrument for loading, playing, and manipulating audio files with pitch/time manipulation and envelope shaping
What It Excels At: Pitch and time manipulation without affecting each other

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Transparent. Sound character determined by loaded sample and processing. Clean playback with various interpolation algorithms.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Velocity-sensitive. Default 55% volume (-5.2 dB) to prevent clipping and allow velocity modulation headroom.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Preserves harmonic content of source sample. Time stretching and pitch shifting can introduce artifacts depending on algorithm selected.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Sample loaded -> Pitch/Time processing -> ADSR envelope -> Filter -> LFO modulation -> Panning -> Output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Sample playback with real-time pitch shifting, time stretching, filtering, and envelope shaping
Key Modules / Sections: Time stretch controls (duration without pitch change)
ADSR envelope (attack, hold, decay, sustain, release)
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Preserves stereo samples. Mono samples can be panned. Stereo width adjustable.

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: N/A (sample-based). Workflow centers on loading and manipulating samples rather than preset browsing.
Best Starting Presets: User-saved templates (drum one-shot, vocal chop, melodic sample)
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: No traditional presets. Save channel states with specific sample processing chains for recall.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.CPU Usage: Very Low. One of the most CPU-efficient playback methods in FL Studio.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Latency: Minimal. Excellent for real-time triggering. Time stretching may add slight latency depending on algorithm.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Real-Time Suitability: Excellent. Designed for real-time performance and sequencing.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Scaling with Polyphony: Scales linearly. Very efficient even with high polyphony. Hundreds of instances possible.

Automation & Integration.Automation Friendliness: Excellent. All parameters automatable. Great for evolving sample manipulation.
Automation & Integration.Link to Controller: Full MIDI learn support. Commonly mapped: pitch, filter cutoff, envelope controls.
Automation & Integration.Patcher Compatibility: Fully compatible. Often used in Patcher for complex sample processing chains.
FL-Specific Features: Drag & drop from browser and Windows Explorer
Piano roll for melodic sample playback

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Direct to mixer channel. Often routed through effects (reverb, delay, distortion). Commonly sidechained to kick.
Beginner Mistakes: Not understanding default 55% volume (-5.2 dB)
Forgetting to set root note for melodic samples
Using wrong time stretch algorithm (artifacts)
Ignoring interpolation quality settings
Not utilizing ADSR for shaping
Over-transposing samples (quality loss)
Not understanding loop points
Pro Tips: Set time stretch to 'Stretch' or 'Pro' for vocals
Use 'Resample' for pitched percussion
Enable high-quality interpolation for final render
Automate start point for rhythmic variations
Layer multiple instances with slight pitch detune
Use reverse for riser effects
ADSR attack for click removal on loops
Velocity to filter cutoff for dynamics
Save channel presets with processing chains

Known Limitations: Limited to basic filtering (no formant preservation)

Learning Curve & Skill Level.Ease of Use: Very Easy. Drag, drop, play. Accessible to absolute beginners.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Visual Feedback Quality: Good. Waveform display, envelope visualization, clear parameter labels.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Documentation Quality: Excellent. Comprehensive FL manual coverage. Abundant community tutorials.

Major Changes Over Time: Time stretching algorithms improved (Stretch Pro added)
Version Notes & Evolution (Optional).Backward Compatibility Notes: Fully backward compatible. Projects from FL 1.x work in current versions.

Plugin Identity.Category: MIDI Control Interface / Internal Controller Generator

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Create custom control interfaces with knobs, sliders, and buttons that can be linked to FL Studio and plugin parameters for unified control and hardware mapping
Best Used For: Aggregating multiple plugin controls in one location
Building macro controls for complex patches
Simplifying parameter access for live performance
What It Excels At: Internal controller creation (auto-generates FL internal controllers)

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: N/A (controller/utility, no audio processing)
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: N/A (does not process audio)

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: User input (GUI/MIDI) -> Internal controller generation -> Parameter linking (global/project) -> Target plugin/FL parameter control
Key Modules / Sections: Control object creator (knobs, sliders, buttons, XY pads)

Primary Controls: Add control objects (knobs, sliders, buttons, etc.)
Link to controller (connect to internal controllers)
Secondary / Advanced Controls: Control object properties (name, color, range, curve)
Macro-Style Controls: All controls function as macros when linked to multiple targets

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: N/A (user-created interfaces, no presets)
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Save control surfaces as presets within plugin. Share/import via FL preset system.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.CPU Usage: Negligible. No audio processing, minimal overhead.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Real-Time Suitability: Excellent. Designed for real-time control and live performance.

Automation & Integration.Automation Friendliness: Excellent. All controls automatable and serve as automation sources for targets.
Automation & Integration.Link to Controller: Primary function. Creates internal controllers and links to hardware MIDI controllers.
Automation & Integration.Patcher Compatibility: Excellent. Commonly used in Patcher for organizing patch controls and exposing parameters.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Standalone in Channel Rack or Patcher. No audio signal chain placement (controller only).
Beginner Mistakes: Confusing global link vs. project link
Not naming controls clearly
Over-complicating interface layout
Forgetting to save control surface presets
Not understanding internal controller auto-generation
Using Dashboard instead (legacy plugin)
Pro Tips: Use 'Override global link' for project-specific mappings
Right-click knob -> Link to controller for quick internal controller access
Right-click target parameter -> Link to controller to connect
Color-code controls for organization
Use in Patcher to expose key parameters
Create hardware controller replicas for visual feedback
Name controls descriptively for easy identification
Save common layouts as presets for reuse
Use XY pads for two-dimensional control

Known Limitations: Requires setup time (not instant like MIDI learn)
Cannot script complex behaviors (use Dashboard API for that)
No preset browser for community templates (manual import)
When NOT to Use It: For simple one-off MIDI mappings (use direct MIDI learn)
When Dashboard scripting is required (legacy projects)

Learning Curve & Skill Level.Ease of Use: Moderate. Interface is clear but linking system requires understanding.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Time to Productivity: Moderate. 10-20 minutes to understand linking. Fast once familiar.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Visual Feedback Quality: Good. Visual controls with bi-directional feedback. Clear labeling.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Documentation Quality: Good. FL manual covers functionality. Community tutorials available for advanced use.

Version Notes & Evolution (Optional).Backward Compatibility Notes: Fully compatible since FL 12. Replaces Dashboard for new projects.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Legacy custom control interface creator for MIDI control and parameter aggregation (superseded by Control Surface for new projects)

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: N/A (controller/utility, no audio processing)
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: N/A (does not process audio)

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: User input (GUI/MIDI) -> Dashboard components -> Parameter linking -> Target control

Macro-Style Controls: All components can function as macros

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: N/A (user-created dashboards)
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Import/export via Dashboard menu. Community dashboards available (e.g., GitHub repositories).

Performance & CPU Characteristics.Real-Time Suitability: Excellent (but Control Surface recommended for new projects).

Automation & Integration.Link to Controller: Good for legacy setups. Control Surface recommended for new projects.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Standalone in Channel Rack. No audio signal chain (controller only).
Beginner Mistakes: Using Dashboard for new projects (use Control Surface instead)
Not understanding it's a legacy plugin
Attempting complex setups without API knowledge
Pro Tips: Use Control Surface for all new projects
Dashboard retained only for legacy project compatibility
If opening old project with Dashboard, consider migrating to Control Surface
Dashboard API available for advanced scripting (developers only)

Known Limitations: Requires API knowledge for advanced features

Learning Curve & Skill Level.Ease of Use: Moderate to Difficult (legacy interface, API scripting complex).
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Time to Productivity: Slow for new users. Control Surface is faster.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Documentation Quality: Good (archived). FL manual retains Dashboard documentation for legacy compatibility.

Major Changes Over Time: Superseded by Control Surface in FL 12.0 (2015)
Version Notes & Evolution (Optional).Backward Compatibility Notes: Fully compatible. Old projects using Dashboard work in current FL Studio versions.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Powerful 16-part multi-timbral sampler with 128-voice polyphony, multi-zone mapping, built-in effects, and extensive sample library format support
Best Used For: Loading Kontakt, Soundfont, EXS24, GIGA libraries
What It Excels At: Multi-format library support (SF2, SFZ, NKI, GIG, AKP, etc.)

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Transparent, high-fidelity sample playback. Sound character determined by loaded samples and library quality. SINC-64 interpolation ensures audiophile-grade playback.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Velocity-sensitive with layering capability. Responds to MIDI velocity, modulation, and expression. Poly/mono/legato modes available.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Preserves harmonic content of source samples. Dual 24dB filters (serial/parallel) can shape harmonic content. No synthesis, pure sample playback.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Sample zones (multi-layer/velocity) -> Pitch/loop processing -> Dual 24dB filters (serial/parallel) -> Modulation matrix (16 slots) -> Built-in effects (reverb, chorus, etc.) -> Output (16 parts)
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Sample playback with real-time SINC-64 interpolation, multi-zone mapping, velocity layering, and modulation routing
Key Modules / Sections: Sample zone mapping (unlimited zones per program)
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Full stereo sample playback. Stereo width control. Dual-mono and stereo zone support.

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Depends on loaded library. DirectWave itself doesn't include extensive factory content but supports professional third-party libraries.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: 128 programs accessible via MIDI program change or plugin menu. Load external libraries via file browser.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.CPU Usage: Very Low. One of the most CPU-efficient samplers available. Ideal for CPU freezing/bouncing VST instruments.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Latency: Minimal. Excellent for real-time playing. HQ SINC-64 interpolation may add negligible latency.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Real-Time Suitability: Excellent. Designed for live performance and real-time sequencing.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Scaling with Polyphony: Scales efficiently. 128-voice polyphony with minimal CPU impact. Can run multiple instances.

Automation & Integration.Automation Friendliness: Excellent. All parameters automatable. Automatable loop points unique feature.
Automation & Integration.Link to Controller: Full MIDI learn. Supports MIDI CC, aftertouch, modulation wheel, expression.
Automation & Integration.Patcher Compatibility: Fully compatible. Often used in Patcher for complex instrument layering.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Direct to mixer channel. Often used with minimal processing (relies on sample quality). Reverb and EQ common in mixing stage.
Beginner Mistakes: Not understanding multi-timbral (16-part) capability
Ignoring modulation matrix (powerful feature)
Loading incompatible Kontakt libraries (NCW compression, scripting)
Not utilizing VST sampling for CPU efficiency
Forgetting to set key ranges for multisamples
Overlooking loop point editor
Pro Tips: Sample CPU-heavy VST synths to DirectWave for efficiency
Use modulation matrix for complex articulations
Import Soundfonts (SF2) for instant instrument libraries
SFZ support for open-source sample libraries
Automate loop points for creative effects
Legato mode with glide for realistic mono instruments
Filter serial mode for steep filtering (48dB/oct)
Multi-output routing for individual part processing
Layer velocity zones for expressive dynamics

Primary Strengths: Extensive format support (SF2, SFZ, NKI, GIG, etc.)
Known Limitations: Basic GUI (not as modern as Kontakt)
Kontakt libraries: no scripting, no NCW compression
Limited visual feedback compared to modern samplers
Not as feature-rich as Kontakt (but far more CPU-efficient)
When NOT to Use It: For single one-shot samples (use Channel Sampler)

Learning Curve & Skill Level.Ease of Use: Moderate. Interface can be overwhelming initially. Powerful once understood.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Time to Productivity: Moderate. 20-30 minutes to understand basics. Hours for advanced multisampling.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Visual Feedback Quality: Moderate. Functional but dated GUI. Zone mapping visual but not as polished as modern samplers.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Documentation Quality: Good. FL manual covers DirectWave. Community tutorials for multisampling techniques.

Version Notes & Evolution (Optional).Backward Compatibility Notes: Fully compatible. DirectWave programs load across all versions since FL 8.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Modular multi-FX guitar-pedal-inspired plugin aggregating distortion types from Harmor, Blood Overdrive, Fast Dist, Soft Clipper, plus filters, chorus, and speaker cabinet simulation
What It Excels At: Consolidating multiple distortion types in one plugin

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Versatile. Ranges from subtle warmth to aggressive destruction. Guitar pedal aesthetic with multiple distortion algorithms. Warm to harsh depending on settings.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Depends on distortion type. Soft Clipper preserves dynamics. Blood Overdrive/Harmor modes compress and saturate. Responsive to input gain.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Adds harmonic richness and overtones. Bit crushing creates aliasing. Rate reduction creates sample-and-hold artifacts. Saturation adds even/odd harmonics depending on mode.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> Pre-Gain -> Distortion Type Selection (Harmor/Blood Overdrive/Fast Dist/Soft Clipper/Bit-Rate Reduction) -> Filter (FLEX filters) -> Chorus (Delay 3) -> Speaker Cabinet Simulation -> Post-Gain -> Output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Modular distortion, filtering, modulation, and cabinet simulation processing
Key Modules / Sections: Bit depth and sample rate reduction
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Full stereo processing. Maintains stereo width. Chorus can enhance width.

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Excellent. 32+ factory presets covering drums, synths, basslines, guitars. Instant results for common use cases.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Presets accessible via plugin menu. Place in Distructor preset folder for integration. User presets saveable.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.CPU Usage: Low to Moderate. Oversampling increases CPU. Efficient for single-band processing.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Latency: Minimal to Low. Oversampling may introduce slight latency (PDC compensated).
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Real-Time Suitability: Good. Suitable for real-time processing. Lower oversampling for live use.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Scaling with Polyphony: N/A (effect plugin). CPU consistent regardless of polyphony.

Automation & Integration.Automation Friendliness: Excellent. All parameters automatable except oversampling quality. Great for filter sweeps and distortion morphing.
Automation & Integration.Link to Controller: Full MIDI learn. Commonly mapped: filter cutoff, distortion amount, mix.
Automation & Integration.Patcher Compatibility: Fully compatible. Can be integrated into complex signal chains. Note: No native multiband (use Patcher + frequency splitter for multiband).
FL-Specific Features: Standard FL automation and MIDI learn
Introduced in FL 20.6 as modern multi-FX solution

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Insert effect on mixer channel. Often used on synths, bass, drums, guitars. Can be pre-EQ for tone shaping or post-EQ for controlled distortion.
Beginner Mistakes: Over-driving input gain (excessive distortion)
Not using mix control (too wet)
Ignoring oversampling (aliasing artifacts)
Not experimenting with distortion types
Using cabinet sim on non-guitar sources inappropriately
Forgetting pre/post gain staging
Pro Tips: Use Patcher + frequency splitter for multiband distortion
Automate filter cutoff for dynamic tone shaping
Bit/rate reduction for lo-fi/retro effects
Mix control essential (parallel distortion)
Cabinet simulation great for synth bass grit
Pre-gain into soft clipper for subtle warmth
Blood Overdrive mode for analog saturation
Chorus section adds movement post-distortion
Oversampling quality critical for final render (avoid aliasing)

Known Limitations: No native multiband processing (requires Patcher workaround)
Cabinet simulation less advanced than dedicated amp sims
Can sound harsh without proper gain staging
When NOT to Use It: For subtle transparent processing (use Soft Clipper alone)
When needing multiband saturation (use Patcher + splitter)
For professional guitar amp simulation (use dedicated amp sim)
When CPU efficiency is critical (simpler plugins available)

Learning Curve & Skill Level.Ease of Use: Easy to Moderate. Interface is intuitive. Guitar pedal aesthetic familiar. Experimentation encouraged.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Time to Productivity: Fast. Good presets provide instant results. 5-10 minutes to understand controls.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Visual Feedback Quality: Good. Clear labeling. Guitar pedal visual style. No spectrum display but intuitive layout.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Documentation Quality: Good. FL manual covers Distructor. Community tutorials growing since FL 20.6 release.

Major Changes Over Time: Aggregated distortion from Harmor, Blood Overdrive, Fast Dist, Soft Clipper
Version Notes & Evolution (Optional).Backward Compatibility Notes: Available from FL Studio 20.6 onward. Projects using Distructor require FL 20.6+.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Single-pad version of the Drumaxx physical modeling engine, designed for synthesizing individual drum sounds (kicks, snares, percussion)
What It Excels At: Low CPU usage (compared to full Drumaxx)

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Organic, resonant, and malleable. Can sound very acoustic or completely alien depending on material settings.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Highly dynamic; physical models respond naturally to velocity changes (timbre changes, not just volume).
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Complex harmonics determined by the 'Material' and 'Shape' settings. Simulates membrane vibration modes.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Exciter (Mallet) -> Membrane Model (Mesh) -> Resonator/Body -> Output

Modulation Capabilities: Velocity modulation is built-in to the physics engine.

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Good starting points for kicks, snares, and cymbals.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Standard menu.

Automation & Integration.Automation Friendliness: Excellent. Automating 'Material' or 'Tension' creates unique morphing effects.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Generator (Source).
Beginner Mistakes: Expecting it to sound like a 909 (it's physical modeling, not analog emulation)
Not using velocity modulation for expressive dynamics
Setting Material too extreme without adjusting Tension
Ignoring the Mallet section (crucial for attack character)
Using identical settings for all drum sounds (each needs unique tuning)
Pro Tips: Automate the 'Tension' parameter for realistic talking drum effects
Use it for 'foley' style sounds by experimenting with weird materials
Layer with sample-based drums for hybrid organic/punchy sound
Mallet Stiffness = hard for click, soft for thud
Combine multiple instances for full physical drum kit
Material settings: low = skin/membrane, high = metal/glass

Primary Strengths: Unique physical modeling sound not achievable with samples
Great for organic textures and experimental percussion
Lightweight CPU usage for what it does
Perfect for IDM, experimental, and cinematic work
Known Limitations: Limited to one sound per instance (unlike Drumaxx)
Learning curve for physical modeling parameters
Not ideal for traditional EDM drums
When NOT to Use It: For standard EDM hits (use samples or FPC)
When needing multiple drums per pattern (use Drumaxx)

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: 16-pad physical modeling drum machine capable of synthesizing realistic and metallic percussion sounds without samples
Best Used For: Creating custom drum kits from scratch
What It Excels At: Simulating drum heads, membranes, and materials
Multi-output routing for individual pad processing
Avoiding the 'machine gun' effect of static samples
Creating unique percussive textures impossible with samples

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Crisp, defined, often metallic or woody. Can lack the 'weight' of samples but excels in definition and response.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Excellent. Modeling engine responds to velocity with timbre changes.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Rich, non-linear harmonics typical of struck objects.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: 16 Pads -> Physical Models (Mesh) -> EQ/Effects -> Output Mixer

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Extensive library of kits.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Integrated kit loader.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Source - often followed by compression and EQ.
Beginner Mistakes: Using it for 808s (not its strength)
Ignoring the multi-out capability
Trying to make it sound exactly like a 909 (it's a modeler, not a sampler)
Overlooking the individual output routing for detailed mixing
Forgetting to use velocity to drive tonal changes
Pro Tips: Route each pad to a separate mixer track for individual processing.
Use the 'Oversampling' option for clearer high-end on cymbals.
Automate the 'Material' parameter per step for melodic percussion lines.
Use the 'Self-oscillation' feature to create drone-like textures.
Layer Drumaxx with a sample-based kick in Patcher for the ultimate punch + texture combo.
Map the 'Tension' parameter to a modulation wheel for expressive live performance.

Known Limitations: Kicks can lack punch compared to samples
Steep learning curve for realistic sound design
Can sound 'synthetic' if not tweaked carefully
CPU usage can rise with high polyphony
When NOT to Use It: For classic 909/808 sounds (use Transistor Bass or Samples)
When you need exact replication of a specific breakbeat
When you need a quick, mix-ready sample pack sound

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Powerful integrated audio editor, recorder, and sampler tool that runs inside FL Studio as an effect plugin
Best Used For: Slicing samples for the Slicex/Fruity Slicer
What It Excels At: Seamless integration with FL workflow (Drag and drop)

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Transparent (Editor).
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: N/A

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> Buffer (RAM) -> Editing/Processing -> Output

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Scripts included.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Scripts menu.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.Real-Time Suitability: Good for recording, not for real-time FX.

FL-Specific Features: Send to Playlist as Audio Clip

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Effect Slot (First for recording, Last for resampling).
Beginner Mistakes: Forgetting to save the sample (it's in RAM)
Recording on the Master channel with effects on
Thinking it saves audio with the project file automatically (it doesn't, unless dragged to playlist)
Using it as a real-time effect processor (it adds latency)
Forgetting to set the tempo information before exporting loops
Pro Tips: Use the 'Claw Machine' tool to generate new rhythms.
Use 'Acquire Noise Profile' -> 'Clean up (denoise)' to remove background hiss.
Right-click the record button to set 'Record on Input' for hands-free recording.
Use the 'Blur' tool to create instant atmospheric textures from any sound.
Scripting in Edison (Pascal) allows for powerful batch processing and effects.
The 'Equalize' tool acts as a linear-phase EQ for surgical spectral cleaning.
Shift+C sends the selection to the Playlist immediately.

Known Limitations: Uses RAM (can fill up with long recordings)
When NOT to Use It: For recording multi-track band sessions (Use Playlist)

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Performance-oriented multi-effect processor designed for live manipulation using an X/Y pad
Best Used For: Quick drastic stylistic changes in arrangements
What It Excels At: Combining simple effects for massive changes
Low CPU overhead for complex sounding effects

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Digital, aggressive, and distinct. Effects are designed to be noticed.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Varies by effect type (Ring mod, Bitcrush add harmonics).

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> Effect Engine (Selectable) -> X/Y Modulation -> Mix -> Output
Key Modules / Sections: 12 Effect Slots (Distortion, Lo-Fi, Flanger, Phaser, Filter, Delay, Reverb, Stereo, Trans, Grain, Vox, Ring)

Modulation Capabilities: X/Y Pad is the main modulation target.

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Good basic setups.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Simple.

Automation & Integration.Automation Friendliness: Excellent. Automate the X/Y parameters for movement.
Automation & Integration.Link to Controller: Perfect for hardware X/Y pads or joysticks.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Master Bus or Group Bus (for transitions).
Beginner Mistakes: Leaving it 'On' without bypass (colors the sound)
Using Reverb from Effector as a main reverb (it's low quality, meant for FX)
Automating the bypass button instead of the Mix knob (can cause clicks)
Forgetting that 'Trans' (Trance) is a gate effect dependent on tempo
Overusing the Bitcrusher without an EQ after it
Pro Tips: Automate the 'Bypass' to engage the effect only on specific beats.
Use the 'Vox' effect for instant formant filtering.
Chain multiple Effectors for complex chains.
Right-click the X/Y pad to 'Create automation clips' for both parameters instantly.
The 'Grain' effect at slow speeds can double as a tape-stop effect.
Use the 'Stereo' effect to retain mono compatibility while widening the sound.
Link the X/Y pad to a hardware joystick for fun live jams.

Known Limitations: 1 effect at a time per instance
Effects are basic quality (not for mixing)
No detailed control over effect parameters outside X/Y

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Modern mastering limiter and loudness maximizer designed to preserve transients and balance while increasing volume
Best Used For: Mastering podcast voiceovers for consistent levels
What It Excels At: Visual feedback of gain reduction and loudness
Visualizing gain reduction vs potential loudness

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Transparent to colored (depending on drive). Modern algorithm.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Low distortion unless pushed.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> Pre-Gain -> Limiter Algorithm -> Post-Gain -> Output

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: N/A (Dynamics tool).
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Standard.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Last on Master.
Beginner Mistakes: Pushing it too hard (distortion)
Not checking True Peak
Ignoring the 'Mode' switch (Transparent vs Punchy suited for different materials)
Setting the Ceiling above -0.1dB for streaming
Assuming it's a compressor (it's a limiter/maximizer)
Pro Tips: Use it for the final 1-2dB of gain, not 10dB.
Use the 'Punchy' mode on drum buses for aggressive glue.
Link the Threshold to a MIDI controller for live loudness interaction.
Automate the Release time for creative pumping effects in break sections.
Use it in Patcher to create multiband maximizing chains.
Keep an eye on the Gain Reduction meter - try not to exceed 3-4dB for transparent mastering.

When NOT to Use It: For creative pumping effects (use a compressor)

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Streamlined version of Emphasis focused on signal coloring, saturation, and tone shaping (a 'mojo' box)
Best Used For: Adding analog-style grit to digital synths

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Warm, saturated, punchy.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Adds even/odd harmonics.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> Saturation Stage -> Limiting Stage -> Output

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Good.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Standard.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Insert or Bus.
Beginner Mistakes: Overdoing the drive
Placing it after the reverb (usually better before)
Forgetting to gain-stage before entering the plugin (it's input dependent)
Using it on the Master bus without checking the mix balance
Ignoring the 'Tone' knob which can drastically change the saturation character
Pro Tips: Use it like a 'Soundgoodizer 2.0' with more control.
Automate the 'Drive' for intensity builds in transitions.
Combine with an EQ before it to target specific frequencies for saturation.
Use the 'Soft Clip' mode for gentle warming vs 'Hard Clip' for aggressive distortion.
Great on 808s to add upper harmonics for small speakers.
Use two instances significantly less driven for a smoother saturation curve.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Morphing graphic equalizer that allows users to draw EQ curves and morph between them in real-time
Best Used For: Cleaning up muddy mixes (Bank switching A/B comparison)

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Digital EQ. Can be transparent or drastic.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Phase shift typical of graphic EQs.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> Graphic EQ Banks (Vol/Pan) -> Morph Engine -> Output

Modulation Capabilities: Morph knob is the primary automation target.

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Good creative shapes.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Standard.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Insert FX.
Beginner Mistakes: Using it for surgical mixing (Parametric EQ 2 is better)
Forgetting to set the banks before morphing
Over-processing frequencies (Graphic EQs obscure bandwidth)
Forgetting to turn off 'Analyze' mode if it was used to capture a curve
Using the 'Mastering' presets (dated, use Parametric EQ 2)
Pro Tips: Draw a low pass shape in bank 1 and high pass in bank 8, then morph for a custom sweep.
Use the frequency panning to spread a mono synth into stereo.
Use the 'Interpolate' function to smooth out rough drawn curves.
Automate the 'Shift' parameter for a phaser-like effect.
Assign the 'Morph' knob to a modulation wheel for expressive filter performance.
Use the 'Analyze' feature to capture the spectrum of a reference track, then invert it for mixing space.
Experiment with the 'Random' curve function for creative spark.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Instant-access preset synthesizer based on Subtractive, Wavetable, Multisample, FM, and AM synthesis engines
Best Used For: Beginners who don't want to program synths
What It Excels At: Low CPU for high quality sounds

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Polished, modern, production-ready. Ranges from realistic acoustic to heavy electronic.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Engine dependent (Subtractive/FM/Sample).

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Hidden Engine (Sytrus/Sample based) -> Macros -> Effects -> Output

Modulation Capabilities: No deep modulation matrix access (by design).

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Exceptional. Industry standard quality.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Tag-based, integrated store.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Generator.
Beginner Mistakes: Thinking you can't edit sounds (you can use Macros)
Ignoring the free packs in the downloader
Assuming it's 'just' a Nexus clone (it has a deep engine)
Not checking the 'Store' tab for free downloads
Overlooking the Arpeggiator tab for rhythmic inspiration
Pro Tips: Automate the Macros; they often control complex under-the-hood parameters like FM amount or Unison width.
Use FLEX for 'Essential' sounds like pianos and strings to save CPU compared to huge Kontakt libraries.
Use the 'General MIDI' library for quick placeholder sounds that are lightweight.
The 'Master Limiter' can be disabled if you want full dynamic range for external processing.
You can drag and drop samples onto the oscillator display in some packs to replace the source.
Save your favorite tweaked presets to a user folder for quick access.
Use the pitch-bend range setting in the wrapper to enable drastic glides for 808s.

Known Limitations: No deep sound design (cannot edit oscillators)
When NOT to Use It: When you need to build a sound from scratch (Use Sytrus/Vital)

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Lightweight piano and organ simulator

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Digital, slightly artificial/thin by modern standards. Has a distinct 'FL' charm.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Sample based.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Sample Playback -> Filter/Drive -> Effects (Stereo/Tremolo) -> Output

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Basic.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Menu.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Generator.
Common Pairings: Fruity Reverb 2 (Essential to make it sound decent)
Beginner Mistakes: Using FL Keys for a final realistic piano ballad (Use FLEX instead)
Not adding reverb
Forgetting to turn off the 'Auto' chord feature if it was enabled by accident
Ignoring the 'Detune' knob which creates a Honky-Tonk feel
Pro Tips: The 'Muffle' knob is great for automated low-pass filter effects without needing an EQ.
It's perfect for complex projects where you need to save RAM.
Add a 'Fruity Convolver' with a high-quality impulse response to arguably make FL Keys sound usable.
Use the 'Overdrive' knob for a gritty electric piano tone.
The 'Release' knob is criticalshorten it for staccato plucks.
Automate the 'Stereo' knob to go from mono verse to stereo chorus.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Electric guitar simulation
Best Used For: Layering with real guitars for artificial bite
What It Excels At: Being a meme in the producer community

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Very artificial, buzzy, and aggressive. Does not sound like a real guitar by modern standards.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Modeling based.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: String Model -> Coil/Pickup -> Amp/Cabinet -> Effects -> Output

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Retro.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Menu.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Generator.
Beginner Mistakes: Expecting it to sound like a real Stratocaster (use FLEX)
Not using the palm mute velocity feature
Trying to make it sound realistic (it won't)
Leaving the cabinet simulation on when using an external amp sim
Ignoring the 'Harmonics' knob which changes the pick position
Pro Tips: FL Slayer is legendary in the Hardstyle community for creating screechy, distorted leads, not real guitars.
Turn off the internal cabinet and run it through Distructor for a better sound.
Use it as a synth pluck rather than a guitar; with some delay, it sounds unique.
Automate the 'Damping' parameter to simulate palm muting rhythmically.
The 'Glissando' switch enables smooth slides between notesessential for solos.
Run it through a heavy distortion plugin like Distructor to hide its artificial nature.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Software MPC-style drum machine for triggering and layering samples
Best Used For: Boom Bap / Hip Hop drum programming
Triggering distinct samples for hi-hat chokes
What It Excels At: Layering multiple samples on one pad
Velocity switching (different samples for hard/soft hits)
Visualizing MIDI note mapping to pads

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Transparent (Sampler). Depends on samples.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: N/A

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Pads (MIDI) -> Layer Manager (Velocity) -> Envelope/Pan/Vol -> Output

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Good high quality acoustic and electronic kits.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Online content library.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Generator.
Beginner Mistakes: Not setting 'Cut/Cut By' for Hi-Hats (Closed hat should cut Open hat)
Putting all drums on one mixer track (Route them out!)
Using it as a synthesizer (it's purely a sample player)
Forgetting to save the kit preset after loading custom samples
Not using the 'Scale Volume' feature to separate layers effectively
Pro Tips: Use FPC to create complex layered snares (e.g., a clap + snare + noise) triggered by one note.
Download the free HQ drum kits from the content manager.
Right-click a pad and select 'Cut itself' for instant 808/sub management.
Drag a loop onto FPC to automatically map slices to pads (if slice markers exist).
Use the 'Midi Loop' player to audition drum patterns before committing to the Piano Roll.
Route pads to 'Main' for a sub-mix channel, then route that channel to the Master.
Layer a noise sample with a short envelope on top of a snare for added 'crack'.

Known Limitations: UI is functional but not fancy

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Shifts the entire frequency spectrum of the audio by a fixed amount (in Hz), destroying harmonic relationships
What It Excels At: Transforming harmonic sounds into inharmonic textures
Stereo widening without phase cancellation issues (if used carefully)

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Metallic, clanging, cold, dissonant. Can be subtle (phasing) or extreme (alien).
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Destroys harmonics (Linear shift vs Logarithmic pitch shift).

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> Frequency Shift / Ring Mod -> Feedback -> Mix -> Output

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Creative.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Simple.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Creative FX chain.
Beginner Mistakes: Confusing it with a Pitch Shifter (It will make things out of tune)
Using too much feedback
Assuming 'Frequency Shift' and 'Pitch Shift' are the same (they are mathematically different)
Leaving the visualizer on 'Input' instead of 'Output' and wondering why nothing changes
Overlapping L/R shifts too much causing phase issues
Pro Tips: Use a very small shift (1-5Hz) mixed in 50% for a unique phaser/chorus effect.
Automate the shift from 0 to 1000Hz on a snare roll for a rising tension effect.
Modulate the 'Feedback' parameter with an envelope follower for dynamic metallic tails.
Use the 'Stereo Difference' knob to create a pseudo-stereo effect on mono sources.
In 'Ring Mod' mode, tune the frequency to the key of your song for harmonic tremolo.
Automate the mix knob to bring in the metallic texture only on impact hits.
Use slight frequency shifting on hi-hats to make them cut through the mix better.

When NOT to Use It: When you want to transpose a melody (Use Pitch Shifter)

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Splits audio into 2 or 3 frequency bands (Low, Mid, High) for independent processing or visualization
Best Used For: Multiband effects processing (e.g., distorting only mids)
Targeted vocal processing (Split breath from body)

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Transparent.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Depends on mode (Linear Phase = Pre-ringing, Minimum Phase = Phase shift).

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> Crossovers -> Band Splits -> Output/Sends

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Utility.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Simple.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.CPU Usage: Low (Higher in Linear Phase High Quality).
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Latency: High (in Linear Phase mode), Zero (in Minimum Phase).

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Beginning of a Patcher chain or Mixer insert.
Beginner Mistakes: Using Linear Phase mode for recording (Latency)
Not muting the main output when sending to sidechains (Doubling volume)
Not checking phase cancellation when using external effects on split bands
Using 'Minimum Phase' mode for parallel processing tasks requiring phase coherence
Forgetting to sidechain the sends in the mixer first
Pro Tips: Right-click the Send number to quickly route to a sidechained mixer track.
Use it to split a bass: Keep Lows mono and clean, Distort and Widen the Mids/Highs.
Use the 96dB slope for surgical bass splitting where you want zero bleed.
Link the cutoff frequencies to a controller to act as a DJ-style isolator.
In Linear Phase mode, use the 'High Quality' setting for mastering tasks.
Visualize the pre/post signal to see exactly how much energy you are redirecting.

When NOT to Use It: If you just need simple EQ (Use Parametric EQ 2)

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Simple single-oscillator kick drum synthesizer for creating basic electronic kick sounds with minimal controls

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Clean, digital, punchy electronic kick. Simple sine-based tone with pitch envelope. No frills, straightforward sound.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Responds to velocity. Pitch envelope creates the characteristic 'thump' of electronic kicks.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Primarily fundamental sine wave with pitch sweep creating initial transient harmonics. Minimal harmonic complexity.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Single Oscillator -> Pitch Envelope -> Amplitude Envelope -> Output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Single oscillator synthesis with pitch and amplitude envelope for classic electronic kick sound
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Mono output (kick drums are typically mono)

Primary Controls: Max Freq (starting frequency of pitch sweep)

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Basic presets covering common electronic kick types. Simple starting points for customization.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Presets found in Browser under /Channel Presets/Fruit Kick. Limited preset selection but fast tweaking.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.CPU Usage: Extremely Low (~0.1% per instance). One of the most efficient kick generators.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Real-Time Suitability: Excellent. Designed for live performance and sequencing.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Scaling with Polyphony: Minimal impact. Kicks are typically monophonic.

Automation & Integration.Automation Friendliness: Excellent. All parameters automatable for kick variations.
Automation & Integration.Link to Controller: Full MIDI learn support for all parameters.
Automation & Integration.Patcher Compatibility: Fully compatible. Works in Patcher for layered drum setups.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Direct to dedicated kick mixer channel. Often first in drum bus routing.
Beginner Mistakes: Setting Min Freq too high (loses sub bass)
Too much distortion (harsh sound)
Ignoring the click parameter
Not layering with samples for complexity
Over-processing the simple output
Pro Tips: Layer with a sample transient for punch
Automate Min Freq for pitch variations
Use for sub layer beneath sample kicks
Keep it simple - complexity comes from post-processing
Duplicate and detune for massive kicks
Route through Fruity Fast Dist for grit

Known Limitations: Very basic - limited sound design options
No built-in EQ or advanced shaping
Cannot compete with modern kick synthesizers
When NOT to Use It: When needing complex, modern kick design

Learning Curve & Skill Level.Ease of Use: Very Easy. Five main controls. Beginner-friendly.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Time to Productivity: Immediate. Create usable kicks in under a minute.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Visual Feedback Quality: Minimal. Simple interface with knobs only.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Documentation Quality: Good. Well documented in FL manual. Simple enough to learn without docs.

Version Notes & Evolution (Optional).Backward Compatibility Notes: Fully backward compatible. Projects from early FL versions work in current versions.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Simple 7-band graphic equalizer for basic frequency shaping with fixed frequency bands and adjustable gain per band
Common Alternatives Inside FL: Fruity Parametric EQ 2 (fully parametric, more control)

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Clean, transparent. Minimal coloration. Fixed frequency bands with smooth transitions.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Static EQ. No dynamic response. Linear gain adjustment.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Transparent. No harmonic addition. Pure frequency adjustment.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> 7 fixed frequency band filters -> Output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Graphic EQ with fixed center frequencies across 7 bands
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Full stereo processing. L/R processed identically.

Modulation Capabilities: Can create filter sweeps via automation

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Basic presets for common EQ curves. Good starting points.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Presets in plugin menu. Simple curve presets for common adjustments.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Analog-style overdrive and distortion effect with variable character from warm saturation to aggressive clipping

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Warm to aggressive. Analog-style overdrive with tube-like saturation at lower settings, harsh clipping at higher settings.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Compresses dynamics as drive increases. Soft clipping preserves some dynamics.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Adds even and odd harmonics depending on settings. Creates classic overdrive harmonic richness.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> Pre-Amp (gain stage) -> Distortion Algorithm -> Color Filter -> Output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Variable overdrive/distortion with pre-amp, color, and drive controls

Primary Controls: Pre-Amp (0-100%, input gain/drive - higher = more into distortion)
Color (tonal character/filter, shifts from dark to bright)

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Good selection of distortion types from subtle to extreme.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.Latency: Zero latency. Perfect for real-time monitoring.

Ignoring the Color control
Not compensating output level
Using X100 mode inappropriately

Automate Pre-Amp for dynamic drive during builds and drops
Color control is key to character - experiment before setting distortion
EQ before distortion shapes which harmonics get generated
Stack with other distortions (e.g., Fast Dist) for complex tones
Use subtly (10-20% distortion) for warmth on master bus or drums
X100 mode is extreme - use for creative destruction only
High Pre-Amp + Low Distortion = different character than reverse

Known Limitations: Can get harsh at extreme settings

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Removes DC offset from audio signals to center the waveform around zero, preventing potential clipping and improving headroom
Best Used For: Cleaning up raw samples recorded with cheap hardware
What It Excels At: Being the 'Global Drip' cleaner for the whole project

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Completely transparent. No audible effect when working correctly.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: None. Pure waveform centering.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> DC Offset Detection -> Offset Correction -> Output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: High-pass filtering or DC offset subtraction

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: N/A - No presets needed.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: No preset system. Single function.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: After distortion or asymmetric processing. Before final limiting.
Beginner Mistakes: Using when not needed
Not understanding DC offset
Ignoring it until the final limiter starts acting weird
Thinking it affects the stereo width (it's DC offset, not stereo center)
Using it on every track 'just in case' (waste of a slot, though zero CPU)
Pro Tips: Insert after heavy distortion
Use before mastering chain
Check waveform in Edison to see DC offset
If your waveform looks asymmetrical in the playlist, drop Fruity Center on it and render in place.
Use it after 'Waveshaper' if you've drawn an asymmetric curve.
Combine with a high-pass filter for ultimate low-end cleanup.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Classic chorus effect using modulated delay lines to create width, movement, and doubling effects

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Classic, warm chorus with gentle modulation. Thickens and widens without extreme processing.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Static effect - applied regardless of input dynamics.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Creates slight pitch detune and phase cancellation for chorus effect.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> Delay Line (modulated by LFO) -> Mix with dry -> Output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Modulated short delay lines with LFO pitch variation
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Creates stereo from mono, enhances existing stereo.

Primary Controls: Delay (1-30ms base delay time, affects chorus thickness)
Depth (0-100% modulation depth, controls pitch variation intensity)
Speed (0.1-10Hz LFO speed/rate, controls modulation tempo)
Wet (0-100% mix amount, blend of effect)

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Good selection of classic chorus types.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Presets in plugin menu.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.CPU Usage: Low (~0.15% per instance). Very efficient modulation effect.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Latency: Minimal (a few ms due to delay buffer).

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: After EQ, before or parallel with reverb.
Beginner Mistakes: Too much depth (sounds watery and pitch-wobbly)
Too fast speed (sounds cheap and seasick)
100% wet (loses original dry signal character)
Using on bass frequencies (causes phase issues)
Not considering mono compatibility
Pro Tips: Use subtle settings (10-20% depth) for vocals to add shimmer
Deeper settings (50%+) work well for synth pads and strings
Automate speed for dynamic movement in builds
Try on clean guitars for classic 80s tone
Combine with delay for lush ambient textures
Use cross delay control for stereo width enhancement
Check mono compatibility - chorus can cause phase cancellation

When NOT to Use It: When needing multi-voice chorus (use Hyper Chorus)

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Basic single-band dynamics compressor for reducing dynamic range and controlling peaks with standard compression parameters

Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Minimal harmonic addition. Transparent dynamics processing.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> Threshold Detection -> Gain Reduction (ratio applied) -> Attack/Release Shaping -> Output

Primary Controls: Threshold (-40dB to 0dB, level where compression begins)

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Basic presets for common compression scenarios.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Presets in plugin menu.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.Latency: Zero latency. Perfect for live monitoring and real-time use.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: After EQ, before reverb. Or on bus for glue.
Beginner Mistakes: Too much compression (over-squashing dynamics)
Setting ratio too high before adjusting threshold
Attack too fast (losing transients)
Release too slow (pumping)
Not using makeup gain
Pro Tips: Use Fruity Limiter for visual feedback while learning compression
Start with gentle ratios (2:1 to 4:1) before going extreme
Match output level to input level using makeup gain
Slower attack (>10ms) preserves transients on drums
Faster release for rhythmic material, slower for vocals
Try the different Type settings for different knee characteristics
Use in parallel (duplicate track, compress one heavily, blend)
Good learning tool - graduate to Fruity Limiter for precision

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Convolution reverb processor using impulse responses to simulate real acoustic spaces and vintage hardware with photorealistic accuracy
Best Used For: Creating unique sound design textures with weird IRs

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Realistic, true-to-life acoustic simulation. Character depends entirely on loaded IR.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Preserves and applies exact harmonic response of IR source.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> FFT Analysis -> Convolution with IR -> IFFT -> Mix with dry -> Output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Full stereo. Supports stereo and true-stereo IRs.

Primary Controls: IR selection (impulse response file - WAV format)
Wet/Dry mix (0-100%, blend convolution with original)
Self-ducking (0-100%, auto-reduces reverb when input present)
Stretch (50-200%, time-stretch IR without pitch change)

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Excellent. Extensive library of real spaces and hardware IRs.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Presets organized by type. Drag custom WAV IRs onto interface.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.CPU Usage: Moderate (~0.5-2% depending on IR length). 1-2 second IRs = ~0.5%, 5+ second IRs = ~1.5%+.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Latency: Low latency mode available (~5ms). Standard mode has latency proportional to IR length.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Real-Time Suitability: Good with short IRs and low latency mode. Long IRs better for offline rendering.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: On send/return for shared reverb. Or insert for specific treatment.
Beginner Mistakes: Using too long IR for the context (muddy, washy sound)
Too much wet signal (loses definition of source)
Not using EQ to shape reverb (conflicts with mix)
Not understanding self-ducking feature (leaves it at 0)
Loading CPU-heavy IRs for live performance
Not matching IR character to source material
Pro Tips: Use self-ducking (30-50%) to avoid mud and maintain clarity
EQ the reverb output - cut lows, shape highs to sit in mix
Layer convolution with algorithmic reverb for complexity
Create custom IRs by clapping in any space and recording
Use stretch for creative effects (slow motion reverb)
Send multiple tracks to one Convolver instance for cohesion
Use cabinet IRs for realistic guitar amp simulation
Short plate IRs work great on snare and vocals
Try reverse IRs for special effects and transitions

Known Limitations: Cannot create new spaces (needs real IRs)

Learning Curve & Skill Level.Ease of Use: Moderate. Simple to use, understanding IRs takes time.
Learning Curve & Skill Level.Time to Productivity: Fast with presets. IR selection requires experience.

Version Notes & Evolution (Optional).Backward Compatibility Notes: Fully backward compatible. Custom IRs saved with project.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Modern feature-rich stereo delay with advanced modulation, filtering, diffusion, and creative controls for professional delay effects

Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Full stereo with offset and width controls.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Multi-band vocoder with envelope followers per band

Known Limitations: Vocodex is more powerful and flexible
Limited band resolution compared to Vocodex
