Using too much unison on low notes
Ignoring the filter envelope
Pro Tips: Use subtle unison for width
Shape bass with filter envelope
Layer with a sub for low end
Use the 'A/B' switch to compare patch variations
Right-click the Arpeggiator to copy patterns to Piano Roll

Known Limitations: Less modulation depth than advanced synths
When NOT to Use It: When you need complex modulation or wavetable synthesis
If you need very detailed sound design control

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Physical modeling synth focused on delicate string resonances and expressive plucked or bowed tones.

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Natural, organic, and resonant with delicate transients.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Highly responsive to velocity and envelope shaping.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Physical modeling with resonant body and string interactions.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Excitation -> string resonators -> body resonance -> output.
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Stereo from resonator positioning and effects.

Macro-Style Controls: Resonance and damping for overall timbre

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: High quality, expressive presets.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Presets live under /Channel Presets/Sakura and are designed for expressive playing.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.Real-Time Suitability: Good, but complex patches may be heavier.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Scaling with Polyphony: Scales with polyphony and resonator complexity.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Generator routed to a mixer insert with reverb for space.
Beginner Mistakes: Using too much resonance leading to harshness
Ignoring damping for realistic decay
Overprocessing with heavy effects
Pro Tips: Use velocity for expressive performance
Layer with subtle reverb for realism
Tame highs with EQ for natural tone
Automate the 'String' model for timbre changes
Use the 'Excitor' noise for bow scrape texture

Primary Strengths: Great for strings and resonant textures
Known Limitations: Not a sampler, so realism is stylized
Learning curve for physical modeling controls
When NOT to Use It: If you require extremely low CPU usage

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Vintage modeling synth designed for punchy, articulated analog-style tones.

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Warm, punchy, and slightly gritty vintage tone.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Classic saw-based subtractive harmonics with filter resonance.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Oscillators -> filter -> amp -> effects -> output.

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Good analog-style presets.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Presets live under /Channel Presets/Sawer.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Generator routed to a mixer insert with EQ and reverb/delay.
Beginner Mistakes: Overdriving the filter
Using too much resonance on basses
Ignoring envelope shape for punch
Pro Tips: Use arpeggiator for instant movement
Automate filter cutoff for classic sweeps
Layer with a sub for weight
Use 'Retrigger' for tight bass timing
Engage 'Vintage' switch for authentic drift and noise

Known Limitations: Not as deep as modern synths

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Legacy virtual analog synth designed for quick live-friendly subtractive sounds.

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Classic digital-analog tone with a slightly gritty edge.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Subtractive waveforms with resonant filter behavior.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Oscillators -> filter -> amp -> output.
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Stereo via unison or effects when used.

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Basic presets for legacy synth roles.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Presets live under /Channel Presets/Simsynth Live.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Generator routed to mixer insert with EQ and reverb/delay.
Beginner Mistakes: Expecting modern wavetable depth
Using too much resonance on basses
Ignoring gain staging
Pro Tips: Use as a lightweight layer
Automate filter cutoff for motion
Pair with saturation for weight
Enable 'Unison' for instant thick leads
Use 'Ring Mod' for metallic bells

Known Limitations: Not as polished as newer synths

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Advanced loop slicer that detects beats, maps slices to keys, and allows reordering and time-stretching.

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Transparent; character depends on time-stretch and slice settings.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Depends on source audio and stretch method.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Audio sample -> slice detection -> slice mapping -> per-slice processing -> output.
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Sample slicing with per-slice envelopes and time-stretching.
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Supports stereo samples and per-slice processing.

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Good presets for slicing workflows.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Presets and demo loops live under /Channel Presets/Slicex and Packs.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.CPU Usage: Low to Medium depending on stretch and polyphony.
Performance & CPU Characteristics.Scaling with Polyphony: Scales with slice polyphony and stretch complexity.

FL-Specific Features: Slice markers with Piano roll mapping

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Generator routed to a mixer insert with EQ and compression.
Beginner Mistakes: Over-slicing resulting in too many tiny slices
Ignoring time-stretch artifacts
Not checking slice mapping in Piano roll
Pro Tips: Use per-slice envelopes for dynamics
Export slices to MIDI for quick rearrangement
Use the Region data if available in the file
Drag 'Dump to score' button for instant MIDI patterns
Use Deck A and B for layering different loops

When NOT to Use It: If you do not need slicing functionality

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: One-knob enhancer based on Maximus for quick loudness, saturation, and presence.
Best Used For: Quick enhancement on drums or vocals
Fast loudness boost for rough mixes

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Punchy, bright, and compressed; adds saturation and loudness.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Aggressive compression and limiting depending on the amount.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Adds harmonics and saturation similar to Maximus presets.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> Maximus-based processing preset -> output.

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Four fixed modes derived from Maximus presets.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Mode buttons choose preset curve; knob adjusts amount.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Insert on individual tracks or buses for quick enhancement.
Beginner Mistakes: Overusing and crushing dynamics
Using on master without monitoring loudness
Stacking multiple instances excessively
Pro Tips: Use subtly for enhancement
Try different modes before adjusting the knob
Compare with Maximus for finer control
Automate the big knob for transitions
Mode A preserves transients well for drums

When NOT to Use It: When you need precise dynamics control

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Generates synthetic speech from text, rendered as audio for creative vocal effects.

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Synthetic and robotic with clear formants.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Formant-based speech synthesis artifacts are part of the tone.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Text input -> speech synthesis engine -> rendered audio output.
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Mono output; stereo via mixer effects.

Modulation Capabilities: Automation of pitch and speed after render
Macro-Style Controls: Pitch and speed for quick character shifts

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Basic. Focused on voice and speed settings.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Speech is typically rendered to audio and then processed in the Playlist or Sampler.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.Real-Time Suitability: Limited. Often used for rendering phrases.

Automation & Integration.Automation Friendliness: Limited pre-render; automation is typically post-processing.
Automation & Integration.Patcher Compatibility: Can be routed after render; not a real-time effect.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Render speech to audio, then route through EQ, compression, and effects.
Beginner Mistakes: Expecting natural-sounding speech
Not rendering to audio for editing
Overprocessing causing intelligibility loss
Pro Tips: Render multiple takes with different pitches
Use vocoder for musical effects
Slice and rearrange phrases for rhythm
Use punctuation (?!.) to change intonation
Space letters (T E X T) for slower articulation

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Simple, modern stereo widening tool designed to expand stereo width while maintaining mono compatibility for low frequencies
Best Used For: Keeping bass frequencies mono while widening highs
Quick stereo enhancement without phase issues
What It Excels At: Modern visualization of the stereo field
Preventing phase cancellation in the low end

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Transparent. Does not color the sound significantly aside from spatial changes.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Manipulates phase/stereo difference signal. Low Bypass filter preserves fundamental harmonics in the center.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> Low Bypass Split -> Stereo Separation Processing (Highs) -> Mono Collapse (Lows) -> Recombination -> Output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Mid-Side (M/S) matrix manipulation with frequency crossover
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Dedicated stereo manipulation tool. Increases Side signal relative to Mid signal above the cutoff frequency.

Primary Controls: Low Bypass (Frequency cutoff for mono safety)
Macro-Style Controls: Separation is the main macro for the entire effect

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Simple utility, few presets needed.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Minimal presets due to simplicity.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Late in the mixing chain, before limiters but after tone shaping. Often on group buses.
Beginner Mistakes: Widening the sub-bass (causing phase issues on club systems)
Not using the Low Bypass knob
Applying 100% separation to everything (messy mix)
Pro Tips: Set Low Bypass around 200-300Hz to keep kick/snare punchy and mono
Automate width to open up during choruses and narrow during verses
Check mix in mono to ensure the 'Spread' signal doesn't disappear
Use on reverb sends for a wider space without muddying the dry signal
Watch the visualizer for excessive phase correlation issues

Primary Strengths: Safest way to widen sound in FL
Low Bypass filter is essential for modern mixing
Known Limitations: Limited control compared to Stereo Shaper
When NOT to Use It: When precise independent L/R delay manipulation is needed (Use Stereo Shaper)

Major Changes Over Time: Introduced in FL Studio 2024 era updates as a modern replacement/alternative to Stereo Enhancer
Version Notes & Evolution (Optional).Backward Compatibility Notes: Only available in newer FL versions.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Powerhouse hybrid synthesizer combining FM (Frequency Modulation), Subtractive, and Additive synthesis with a modulation matrix
What It Excels At: Unbeatable versatility (can sound like almost anything)

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Clean, digital, and precise. Can be warm (filters), cold/metallic (FM), or aggressive (Waveshaping). High-fidelity audio engine.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Extremely dynamic due to FM nature. Velocity can modulate any operator parameter.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Infinite. User can draw custom harmonic partials for each operator. FM creates complex non-harmonic sidebands.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: 6 Operators (Oscillators) -> Modulation Matrix (FM/RM routing) -> 3 Filter Units (SVF/Mango) -> 3 Effects Units (Chorus/Delay/Reverb) -> Output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Frequency Modulation (FM), Ring Modulation (RM), Subtractive (Filters), Additive (Oscillator shape editor)
Key Modules / Sections: Filter Section (3 independent filters with waveshapers)
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Full stereo unison, per-operator panning, stereo delay/chorus effects.

Modulation Capabilities: Complex multi-segment envelopes for every parameter.
LFOs, Velocity, Keyboard tracking mappings for everything.
Macro-Style Controls: X/Y Pad (Modulation source for almost anything)

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Excellent and vast. Hundreds of factory presets covering all genres.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Can import Yamaha DX7 SysEx data directly.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.CPU Usage: Low to Moderate. Very efficient for its power. High unison/oversampling increases load.

Automation & Integration.Automation Friendliness: Good, but many parameters are hidden in tabs. Use X/Y pad for performance automation.
Automation & Integration.Patcher Compatibility: Excellent. Sytrus is often used as a modular building block in Patcher.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Source instrument.
Beginner Mistakes: Touching the Matrix randomly (creates noise)
Not understanding Operator Ratios
Overusing Unison (CPU spikes)
Pro Tips: Right-click an operator to 'Analyze Audio' and resynthesize samples
Use the 'Pluck' mode in the delay section for Karplus-Strong synthesis
Drag and drop DX7 SysEx files onto Sytrus to load classic 80s patches
Use the waveshaper in the filter section for grit/distortion
Enable 'Gibbs' in harmonics editor to smooth out sharp edges
Use 'Global' tab quality settings to save CPU during composition

Known Limitations: Effects section is older (but still good)
When NOT to Use It: When you need a simple, quick sound (unless using presets)
For hyper-realistic acoustic emulation (better to use DirectWave)

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Visual programming environment for creating VST instruments and effects within FL Studio
What It Excels At: Visual modular programming (drag and drop wires)

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Variable. Depends entirely on what you build.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: N/A

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Modular. User defined.

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Variable.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Included a library of examples.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Anywhere.
Beginner Mistakes: Using it expecting a standard synth (it's a dev tool)
Pro Tips: Use Patcher for 90% of tasks; use SynthMaker/Flowstone only if you need low-level DSP
Check the forums for huge libraries of user-created modules

When NOT to Use It: In modern 64-bit FL Studio workflows (use Patcher)

Major Changes Over Time: Rebranded as FL Flowstone in later versions
Eventually deprecated in favor of 64-bit architecture (Flowstone 64 is separate)
Deprecated Features: The entire plugin is largely legacy in modern FL.

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Cinematic and aggressive FM/Subtractive hybrid synthesizer with a focus on 'toxic', distorted, and atmospheric sounds

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Aggressive, digital, cold, gritty, and cinematic. Less 'clean' than Sytrus, more characterful.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Rich in aliasing and digital artifacts (often desirable for this synth).

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: 6 Oscillators (Custom Waves) -> FM Matrix -> Filter -> 2 LFOs -> Effects (Distortion, Chorus, Delay, Reverb) -> Output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: FM Synthesis mixed with Subtractive filtering

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Good, focused on darker genres.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Standard list browser.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Source.
Beginner Mistakes: Comparing it to modern wavetable synths (it's an older hybrid)
Overcomplicating the FM matrix
Pro Tips: Import your own single-cycle waveforms for unique oscillator sounds
Use the built-in distortion for that signature 'Toxic' sound
Automate the FM matrix for evolving textures
Use the sequencer to drive external gear via MIDI out (if supported)
Layer with a sub-bass for a complete industrial sound

Known Limitations: Sound palette can be 'dated' for some modern genres
Filter is not as smooth as newer plugins

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Dynamics processor that shapes the Attack and Sustain of a sound independent of its level (compression-like but transient-focused)
Best Used For: Removing room reverb from drum recordings (De-verb)
What It Excels At: Split frequency processing (Mid/Side or Frequency split)

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Transparent. Enhances impact or sustain.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Clean, unless driven into saturation (which it doesn't do natively).

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> Transient Detection -> Attack/Release Gain Application -> Output

Secondary / Advanced Controls: Split Frequency (Process only highs or lows)

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Good utility presets.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Minimal.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Insert effects, often before compression.
Beginner Mistakes: Using it as a compressor (it's not)
Over-boosting attack causing clipping
Pro Tips: Use negative Release to remove room noise from drum loops
Use the Split Frequency to add click to a kick without affecting the sub boom
Boost attack on parallel compression buses for extra smack
Soften pick attack on acoustic guitars for a smoother sound
Automate the 'Attack' knob for build-ups

Known Limitations: Not a multiband processor (only one split point)
Can sound unnatural if pushed too hard
When NOT to Use It: On smooth pads (no transients to detect)
When standard compression is needed for leveling

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Faithful emulation of the Roland TB-303 Bass Line synthesizer, famous for Acid House and Techno

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Resonant, squelchy, biting, and analog. Can be smooth (sine-like) or screaming (distorted).
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Classic 18dB/octave low pass filter behavior with unique resonance character.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Oscillator (Saw/Square) -> 18dB Filter -> VCA -> Distortion Unit -> Delay/Reverb -> Output
Key Modules / Sections: Filter Section (Cutoff, Res, Env Mod, Decay, Accent)

Modulation Capabilities: Internal sequencer handles the 'Slide' and 'Accent' logic best.

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Excellent authentic Acid patterns.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Internal pattern browser.

FL-Specific Features: Can be played via Piano Roll or Internal Sequencer

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Source.
Beginner Mistakes: Trying to play chords (it's monophonic)
Not using Slides/Accents (key to the sound)
Pro Tips: Automate Cutoff and Resonance together for classic Acid sweeps
Use the internal sequencer for the most authentic 303 glide behavior
The distortion unit is powerful; don't overlook it
Program slides by overlapping notes in the Piano Roll
Use the 'Accent' threshold to create dynamic patterns

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Real-time audio re-looper and mashup tool that captures live audio into a buffer and triggers loops based on transient detection
Best Used For: Creating variation in repetitive drum beats
What It Excels At: Transient-driven loop triggering (different from grid-based Gross Beat)
Visualizing the loop buffer in real-time

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Glitchy, rhythmic, stuttering. Depends on input.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Transient driven - reacts to the rhythm of the input.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Preserves pitch (mostly re-triggering audio).

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> Rolling Buffer (Recording) -> Transient Detector -> Playhead Jump (to previous transients) -> Output
Key Modules / Sections: Loop A / Loop B (Dual loop engines)

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: N/A (Effect depends on input)
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Minimal.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.Latency: Depends on buffer settings, generally intended for real-time.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Master bus or Drum Bus (for fills/glitches).
Beginner Mistakes: Putting it on a silent channel (needs input)
Confusing it with a standard sampler
Pro Tips: Use 'Deterministic' mode for repeatable stutter patterns
Automate the Mix knob to bring in chaos only during transitions
Map 'Sensitivity' to a controller for live glitch performance
Use on a vocal bus for instant 'chopped' effects
Experiment with 'Probabilistic' mode for generative fills

Known Limitations: Less precise control than Gross Beat for specific patterns
When NOT to Use It: When you need a precise 1/4 note trance gate (Use Gross Beat)

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Real-time chromatic tuner for checking the pitch of audio inputs (guitars, vocals, synths)

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: N/A (Analysis only). Does not affect sound.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Detects the fundamental frequency (pitch).

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> Pitch Detection Algorithm -> Visual Output -> Output (Thru)

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: N/A
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: N/A

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: First in the chain for recording instruments.

Leaving it on while mixing (distracting visual)
Pro Tips: Use it to tune your 808s samples to C so they map correctly on the keyboard
Change the Reference Frequency if you are working in 432Hz or other tunings
Place first in the effects chain for accurate detection
Use the 'Strobe' mode for the finest tuning precision

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Advanced pattern arpeggiator and step sequencer designed to be used within Patcher to drive other instruments
What It Excels At: Converting simple chords into complex rhythmic patterns
Deep control over velocity, gate, and pitch per step

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: N/A (MIDI Effect).
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Controls harmony via Pitch steps.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: MIDI Input -> Step Sequencer/Arp Engine -> MIDI Output -> Target Instrument

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Good functional presets.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Internal preset system.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.Latency: Processing latency dependent on Patcher chain.

FL-Specific Features: Designed specifically for the VFX architecture

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Before a synth in Patcher.
Beginner Mistakes: Trying to load it as a standard effect (it's a Patcher plugin)
Not connecting the MIDI cables in Patcher
Pro Tips: Chain multiple VFX Sequencers for polyrhythmic madness
Use the 'Color' output to trigger different MIDI channels/instruments from one sequence
Automate the 'Pattern' selector to switch grooves mid-song
Use the 'Chord' mode to generate complex arpeggios from simple triads
Copy patterns between Voice tabs for layered sequences

When NOT to Use It: If you prefer working strictly in the Piano Roll
For simple arps (use the Channel Rack settings)

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Analog-style chorus for thickening and widening audio using modulated delay lines
Best Used For: Thickening vocals with a subtle blend

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Warm, slightly lo-fi chorus with gentle pitch modulation and stereo spread.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: LFO-driven modulation; input level mainly affects output level.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Adds comb filtering and mild pitch variation; no new harmonics unless driven.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> modulated delay lines -> wet/dry mix -> output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Stereo width created via phase-offset modulation and wet mix.

Modulation Capabilities: Internal LFO controls modulation rate and depth

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Useful bread-and-butter chorus presets.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Presets cover intensity ranges; tweak mix and depth to fit the source.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Insert after synth/guitar, often before reverb and delay.
Beginner Mistakes: Too much depth/feedback causing seasick modulation
Using 100% wet on full mixes
Applying heavy chorus to sub-bass without filtering
Pro Tips: Use a subtle mix for width
Automate mix for chorus/verse contrast
High-pass the wet signal to keep low end mono
Crank the 'Depth' for a seasick lo-fi vibrato effect
Use on mono synths to instantly place them in the stereo field

When NOT to Use It: When you need pristine micro-pitch or multi-voice chorus
On critical mono low-end without parallel filtering
If you need complex modulation routing

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Classic phaser effect using modulated all-pass filters for sweeping notches

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Warm, swirly, vintage phaser with gentle coloration.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: LFO-driven; input dynamics mostly pass through unchanged.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Phase cancellation creates moving notches and resonant peaks.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Input -> all-pass filter stages -> feedback -> wet/dry mix -> output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Phase modulation via all-pass filter network
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Stereo movement via phase offsets between left and right.

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Useful variety from subtle to extreme.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Presets help quickly choose sweep depth and rate.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Insert on synths or guitars, often before reverb and delay.
Beginner Mistakes: Too much feedback causing harsh peaks
Very fast rates that blur the source
Phasing mono bass without parallel blend
Pro Tips: Tempo-sync rates for rhythmic sweeps
Blend with dry signal for clarity
Automate feedback for build-ups
Use 'Manual' mode with automation for precise frequency notches
Drive the input for a grittier, saturated phase tone

When NOT to Use It: When you need complex, multi-stage phasing
For transparent tone shaping without modulation

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Vocoder that imprints modulator (voice) articulation onto a carrier for robotic and synthetic vocal effects
Best Used For: Creative FX on drums or textures

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Clean, digital vocoder tone that can be smooth or robotic depending on settings and carrier.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Tracks modulator envelope; attack/release controls articulation.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Imprints modulator formants onto the carrier via filter bank processing.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Modulator input -> analysis filter bank -> carrier input -> synthesis filter bank -> output
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Stereo carrier supported; width preserved or enhanced based on settings.

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Good selection covering classic and creative vocoder sounds.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Use presets to establish tone, then adjust bands and release for clarity.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.Scaling with Polyphony: Scales with band count and carrier polyphony

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Insert on a mixer track with the modulator routed in; use a synth or internal carrier.

Using too few bands for intelligibility
Running 100% wet with no dry blend
Pro Tips: Use a bright saw carrier for clear consonants
Compress the modulator for steadier articulation
Automate formant shift for expressive movement
Enable 'Soundgoodizer' (SG knob) for instant brightness
Use the 'Sidechain' input to vocode drums with loops

Known Limitations: Can sound synthetic without careful setup
When NOT to Use It: When you need a quick, no-routing effect

Learning Curve & Skill Level.Time to Productivity: Short setup time once routing is understood

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Multi-mode audio visualizer (oscilloscope, spectrum, vectorscope, peak meter, spectrogram)

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Expanded Wasp synth with more control and modulation options for bigger sounds
What It Excels At: Fast sound design with extra control

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Similar gritty Wasp tone with expanded control; can be cleaner or more aggressive.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Standard envelope/velocity response with additional modulation options.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Analog-style harmonics with resonant filter emphasis.

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Oscillators -> mixer -> filter -> amp -> output with expanded modulation
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Stereo width via voicing/unison or external effects.

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Good variety across basses, leads, and pads.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Presets demonstrate the expanded modulation options.

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Channel rack synth routed to mixer with modulation and effects.
Beginner Mistakes: Overusing unison and causing phase blur
Ignoring gain staging with stacked voices
Relying on presets without adjusting filter envelopes
Pro Tips: Keep unison modest for clarity
Use filter envelope for punch
Layer with a clean sub for weight
Automate the 'Tone' knob for thin-to-fat variations
Use LFO2 to modulate LFO1 rate for chaotic textures

Known Limitations: Less advanced than modern wavetable/FM synths
When NOT to Use It: When you need complex modulation matrices
If you want integrated FX and advanced routing

Core Purpose & Use Case.Primary Function: Real-time visual generator for audio-reactive visuals and music video rendering
Best Used For: Layered video FX inside FL Studio

Sound Character & Behavior.Overall Sound Character: Visual-only; audio passes through unchanged.
Sound Character & Behavior.Dynamic Response: Audio-reactive controllers respond to incoming audio and automation.
Sound Character & Behavior.Harmonic Behavior: Not applicable (visual plugin).

Signal Flow & Architecture.Internal Signal Flow: Audio input -> analysis/controllers -> visual layer stack -> output render
Signal Flow & Architecture.Synthesis / Processing Method: Layer-based visual synthesis with audio-reactive modulators
Signal Flow & Architecture.Stereo Handling: Stereo analysis can drive modulation; audio output unaffected.

Presets & Workflow.Preset Quality: Good selection of ready-made visualizer styles.
Presets & Workflow.Preset Browser Notes: Start with a preset, then swap layers or controllers.

Performance & CPU Characteristics.CPU Usage: Moderate to High (depends on resolution and layers)

Common Use Patterns.Typical Signal Chain Placement: Master bus or a dedicated mixer track feeding audio to the visualizer.
Beginner Mistakes: Rendering at full resolution while previewing
Overloading layers and dropping frames
Forgetting to route audio to the plugin
Pro Tips: Use lower resolution for preview and full resolution for final render
Drive controllers with a clean, compressed signal
Render offline for best quality
Use 'Add Content' to bring in your own images and 3D models
Stack 'PostProcess' effects for cinematic looks (bloom, vignette)

When NOT to Use It: When you only need basic audio metering
On low-end systems during live playback

Learning Curve & Skill Level.Time to Productivity: Short with presets; longer for custom scenes
